column4: gross_anatomy
column5: diagnostic_traits
compound umbels, dissected leaves, schizocarp fruits
Yellow flowers; 2nd umbels unequal distances from each other due to variable length of rays;  individual leaflets few, virtually always greater than 5mm wide
Yellow flowers; 2nd umbels unequal distances from each other due to variable length of rays;  individual leaflets few, many times longer than wide
umbel, white sap, corolla with a tube and appendage (hood and horn), fused anther filaments, pollen shed in pollinia
many flowers compose a single head (capitulum), stigma with ‘lines’, fruit a cypselae, cypselae often dispersed with modified calyx (pappus) intact, often two types of flowers (ray, disk).
Only ray flowers present (capitula ligulate), generally milky sap, petal like zygomorphic limb of ray corolla with 5 lobes. Ray flowers many colours.

capitula generally beset with bristles (palea) from the base (receptacle) which often enclose the disk flowers, cypselae with generally low scalelike pappus, anthers often dark, ray flowers generally yellow.

column4: Leaves deeply divided to the midrib from a basal rosette
column5: with a few stems each ending in a single radiate flower head.

column4: Large clumped plants with huge nearly upright arrow shaped leaves
column5: many stalks each ending with a single radiate  flower head.
Heads (generally) with both ray and disk flowers (radiate),  phyllaries in 3-many series, ray flowers many colours

column4: phyllaries in one whorl; generally many very narrow (<~1.5mm) ray limbs

column2: tightly bunched herb with scapose stems
column4: entire narrowly oblanceolate leaves nearly vertical; appearing to lack ray flowers; single capitula per stem; phyllaries hairy

column2: tightly bunched herb with stems terminated by single capitulum
column4: entire linear leaves nearly vertical; yellow ray flowers; lower cauline leaves clasping the stem;

column2: tightly bunched herb with leafy stems
column4: Many stemmed plants, with dense stiff hairs all over; the  narrow slightly oblanceolate leaves reduced in size along the stems. Each flower head with many white - light pink-blue narrow ray flower limbs.

column2: tall loosely bunched herb with leafy stems
column4: stems well branched with several to many capitula; leaves essentially glabrous throughout and three nerved; ray limbs white to violet

column2: single stemmed herb from basal rosette
column4: basal rosette of grayish, multi-lobed, lacy leaves; disc flowers only;  flowers pinkish to white; 1-2 ft tall
The leaves are mostly basal, prominently veined, entire and tufted, with cauline leaves reduced upward, becoming sesslie
Palmate leaves with 3-5 leaflets,; very long stamens; pods long siliques subtended by both pedicels and long stipitate stalks

column5: corolla (almost always) of three types of petals (banners, flags, keel); usually 9 stamen with filaments fused at base; fruit a dry dehiscent capsule (legume) leaves generally pinnate.

column4: incurved to erect stipitate fruits; calyx with black hairs
the few sparse leaflets very narrow; slender, single chambered,  legumes on long stipes; flowers creamy white with banner reflexed ~90*

column5: Herbage generally with sunken flat glands and smelling when bruised; flowers not forming distinct keels, banners, and wings;  Petals with narrow bases and wide upper portions; leaves pinnate; stipules small; androecium often reduced to 5.

column4: foliage glabrous up to inflorescence, subglaucescent;  corollas purplish;; flowers remaining densely packed in age
foliage slightly pilose to glabrous up to infloresence,  often glaucescent; corollas purplish; distance between flowers increasing in age ;

column5: Stamens fused (connate)- forming a tube which is attached (adnate) to the base of the petals (corolla) and surrounds the lower portions of the gynoecium
column7: a dry dehiscent fruit resembling a wheel of cheese

column4: Leaves somewhat triangular, weakly 3-lobed and 3-veined, with wavy margins and rounded teeth
Leaves are divided over halfway to the midrib and moderately to sparsely pubescent, veins prominent from underside

column5: florets w/ only one spikelet; lemmas indurate (clasping the fertile organs) with a callus at base,;lemma generally awned from near tip; the awn often bent

column4: Lemmas 3-6 mm, with long silky hairs; panicle branches open and spreading in erratic directions; ligule 2.5-8 mm
awn of lemma attached beneath the end of it (subterminal); glumes broad at base and tapering rapidly to tip; lemmas hairs short < 1.5mm; awn hairs short; apical lemma lobes ~ 1mm

the short (10-22 mm) awn bent twice, the lowest portions often twisted like a barbershop pole, and sparsely hairy; the hairs of  the (4.5 - 7 mm) lemma short, the tuft of hairs at the tip near the awns point of attachment < 1.5 mm; lemma not tightly closed upon itself
Awn of lemma bent twice; hairs of lowest awn segment shorter than lemma; palea generally > 1/2 the lemma length
Awn of lemma bent twice; hairs of lemma and lowest awn segment a similar length; palea generally < ½ the lemma length
Awn of lemma bent once, with long hairs (4 – 8 mm) beneath the bend
Lemma short hairy; ligules 2-7 mm; glumes purplish; mature awn bent twice, and hairy on the two lowest section
body of lemma covered with dense spreading, and long (2-5 mm) soft hairs; plants < 2.5 dm tall; awn  tending to fall at seed maturity
Awn very long 7-16 cm; lemma long (8- 1 4mm); glumes very long (15-35 mm)

column5: Inflorescence with sessile spikelets located on opposite sides of culm  (distichous)

column4: caryopsis disarticulating beneath the glumes; glumes narrowed to long (3-8 cm) nearly linear bristles (subulate);  generally 2-3 spikelets borne side by side on the culm; lemmas with long  (2-12cm) awns, generally bending to 90* when mature; inflorescence often appearing purpleish
plant generally > 7 dm tall; auricles evident; leaf blades, thick, flat and broad (4-15 mm); glumes long (7-16 mm) and narrow linear (subulate)
lemmas awned or awnless; spikelets on opposite sides of the rachis and alternating; spikelets sessile on rachis; glumes membraneous

column5: no single set of traits…

column4: infloresence a moderately condensed panicle; leaf tips prowshaped; leaf collars, and occasionally the cut ligules, with some hairs;
Infloresence a moderately open panicle of ascending branches; lemmas with 2-6 mm awns
infloresence a moderately congested panicle; leaves with a prow shaped tip;  ligule of cauline leaves to 2.5 mm
ligule a cut membrane or fringe of hairs; plants glaucous; spikelets clearly long soft hairy from the base
spikelets with one floret; collar and leaf sheath near ligule of long soft hairs; lemmas awnless and 1-nerved

column5: Typically, 3 petals and 3 sepals barely distinguishable (tepals); Achene long and flat or more generally 3 sided
Tepals 6, achenes long and three sided.

column4: Flowers held in large open umbels often with multiple herbaceous bracts; flowering stems usually with a whorl of leaves mid-stem; leaves long and lanceolate,  the upper surface often curled inwards below; with dense appressed hairs, these often falling in patches as the plant ages
column5: Stipitate perianths

column4: Flowers held in tight nearly rounded heads (capitate) at the end of long naked stems; Tepals easily distiguishable as two whorls; Plant hairy
Bright yellow flowers; broadly ovate leaves from an evident petiole which are generally green above and hairy-woolly below; large herbaceous bracts at base of umbel

column5: Corolla of 5 petals fused below, but forming two lips above; stamens generally 1-2 or 4-5

column2: herbs with few to many erect-ascending stems
column4: leaves both basal and cauline; caulines leaves opposite; flowers whorled on stem (verticillasters); flowers with 5 fused corollas splitting into an 2 lobed upper and three lobed lower lip; the fifth stamen is sterile, sometimes hairy
column5: Corolla distinctly two-lipped at end; four stamens and a fifth sterile (oftentimes) hairy staminode present

column2: decumbent to erect, multiple stemmed, herb
herb with many clustered decumbent/erect stems
column4: flowers white, often mostly facing the same direction (secund);
flowers many, red, the upper and lower lips scarcely distinguishable;
Flowers blue, with a not well differentiated throat and mouth; staminodes with dense orange hairs
foliage glaucescent, and mostly located along the very tall stems; flowers light pink, with wide mouths, and an almost protruding staminode with orange hairs
Flowers blue, with a wide mouth and notably narrow at the base (throat); plants generally lacking both glands and hairs throughout
